columns.text: In this exercise, we are asked to determine the cross-rate and the arbitrage profit.

An **exchange rate** is the value of a country's currency *when expressed in another country's currency.*

The exercise give us the exchange rate of Japanese Yen which is ¥114 = $1 and exchange rate of British pound exchange rate which is £1 = $1.26.

## a.

We are asked to determine the cross-rate in terms of yen per pound.
A **cross-rate** is an implicit exchange rate of two currencies *quoted by another currency.*

We will determine the cross-rate for Japanese yen in terms of British pounds. The value of the Japanese yen when expressed per U.S dollars is **¥ 114**. On the other hand, the value of pounds when express in U.S dollars is **$ 1.26**.

To determine how many Japanese yen we can get for a pound, we will multiply the value of the Japanese yen when expressed per U.S dollars and the value of pound when expressed in U.S dollars.

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{Japanese yen (¥)} &= \text{¥ per U.S \$} \times {{\text{£ in U.S \$}}}\\
&= \text{¥ 114} \times {{\text{\$ 1.26}}}\\
& = \boxed{\text{¥ 143.64}}
\end{aligned}$$
\
We can get **¥ 143.64** per pound.
As a conclusion, the cross-rate for Japanese yen in terms of British pounds is **¥ 143.64 per pound.**

## b.

We are asked to determine if there is an arbitrage opportunity if the cross-rate is is ¥147 = £1.
**Arbitrage opportunities** are opportunities for risk-free profits.

The cross-rate is ¥147 = £1. Since it is higher than the exchange rate of Japanese yen to U.S. dollar is ¥114 = $1, it is risk-free investment since you can gain more profit as the Japanese yen is higher if quoted in British pounds.. Therefore, **there is an arbitrage opportunity**.
\
Since there is an arbitrage opportunity, we need to explain how to to take advantage of the mispricing and the potential arbitrage profit.

First, we need to determine the exchange rate of pound per U.S dollar. We will divide one pound  by the exchange rate of U.S dollar $1.26 which is given in the exercise.

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{British £} &= \dfrac{\text{1 £}}{\text{Exchange Rate}}\\[10pt]
&= \dfrac{\text{1 £}}{\text{\$ 1.26}}\\[10pt]
&=\boxed{\text{£ 0.7937}}
\end{aligned}$$
\
The value of the British pound per U.S dollar is **£ 0.7937.**

Recall that the cross-rate is ¥147 = £1. Suppose that we invest $ 1. We will convert it pound to buy a Japanese yen. To determine the amount of Japanese yen we can get, we will multiply the value of a dollar in pound to the cross rate of ¥147 as follows:

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{British Pounds (£)} &= \text{£ per dollar} \times {{\text{Cross Rate of ¥ }}}\\
&= \text{£ 0.7937} \times {{\text{¥ 147}}}\\
& = \boxed{\text{¥ 116.6739}}
\end{aligned}$$
\
For $ 1, if we used the cross-rate, we will get **¥ 116.6739**.
The value of the ¥ 116.6739 when converted back to U.S. dollar is **$1.0235**. Since we have invested $1, we have an **arbitrage profit of $0.235**. ($1.0235 - $1)
As a conclusion, the cross-rate is **¥ 143.64 per pound** and the arbitrage profit is **$0.235**
